items.title: The irreducible core of all 8 principles
items.content:
One sentence: Context is finite, so externalize state, prefer fresh instances, separate concerns, verify everything, and communicate explicitly.

If you forget everything else, remember this.

items.title: Principles = Physics, Patterns = Engineering
items.content:
Knowing Newton's laws doesn't make you an engineer, but without them you can't explain why bridges stand.

Principles: Explain WHY patterns work
Patterns: Show WHAT to build

Master principles to debug failures and create new patterns.

items.title: Why Context Is the ROOT constraint
items.content:
IF context were infinite
THEN you could:
- Keep all state in conversation (no P2)
- Run one long session forever (no P3)
- Mix planning and execution freely (no P4)
- Make tasks any size (no P5)

Context finitude FORCES every other principle.

items.title: What if we had infinite context?
items.content:
You'd design: One session per project, state in conversation, no restarts needed.

Why this fails anyway: Attention mechanisms degrade. Even with 10M tokens, transformer attention doesn't scale linearly.

Finite context is physics, not a temporary limitation.

items.title: Which document for which stage?
items.content:
Beginner: "What are the rules?" -> Core Principles
Intermediate: "Why does this fail?" -> Anti-Patterns
Advanced: "How do I improve over time?" -> Learning Loops
Staff: "How do I create new patterns?" -> Derivation Guide

Most engineers stop at Intermediate. Staff+ requires Derivation.

items.title: Ryan Carson on Compounding
items.content:
"What's amazing is I can ask it to look at previous runs to learn what worked or didn't work. So every time I run Ralph, it gets better and better."

Run 10 dramatically outperforms Run 1 when learning loops are implemented.

items.title: Not in the Principles section?
items.content:
For patterns: -> Architecture section
For specific implementations: -> Mastery section
For tool comparisons: -> Compare section
For transformations: -> Transform section

items.title: Principle conflicts are real
items.content:
P3 (Fresh) vs. P2 (External):
Fresh context means losing in-memory state. External state means read overhead each iteration.

Resolution: Accept read overhead (~5-10s) as the cost of consistent quality.

Principles don't eliminate trade-offs; they clarify which side to choose.

items.title: How principle understanding evolves
items.content:
Week 1: "These seem like arbitrary rules"
Month 1: "Oh, context rot is real"
Month 3: "I can predict when patterns will fail"
Month 6: "I derive patterns for new constraints"

Patience. Principles become intuition with practice.

items.title: What's still unsolved
items.content:
Optimal context compaction: When exactly to reset vs. extend?
Cross-project transfer: Which learnings generalize?
Principle 9+: Are there undiscovered fundamental constraints?

The 8 principles are current consensus, not final truth.
